did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Milling Family Papers primarily contain correspondence between members of the Milling family around and during the American Civil War. Financial documents and a copy of a 1997 issue of Confederate Veteran are also included.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: David Milling (1797-1867), a native of County Down, Northern Ireland, owned a plantation in Fairfield County, South Carolina. He and his first wife (probably a cousin), Jane Wright Milling Milling (1806-1847), had six children together: John R. Milling (1825-1864), Dr. James S. Milling (1831- 1895), David Y. Milling, Jr. (1833-1895), Thomas H. Milling (born 1840), William Milling (born 1842), and Margaret Milling (born 1844). Jane Wright Milling Milling died in 1847.

David Milling later married Sarah Yongue Milling (1823-1893). David and Sarah Milling had five children together: Robert Russell Milling (1844-1893), Andrew Yongue Milling (1851-1909), Mary Agnes Milling Lemmon (1854-1934), G. Ladson H. Milling (1860-1935), Lenora E. Milling Macfie (1864-1936).

Two of Milling’s sons, David Y. Milling, Jr. and John Milling, moved to Texas prior to the Civil War. They settled in Anderson County, Texas. These two, plus William, all served in the American Civil War on the Confederate side. John R. and William Milling both enlisted in Company D, 6th South Carolina Infantry, John as a 1st Lieutenant and William as a sergeant. John, a soldier in the Boyce Guards of the 6th South Carolina Infantry, died in the war in 1864.

James S. Milling studied at the Medical College of South Carolina until 1854 and married his cousin Mary (1828-1913) in 1857. Two years later he moved his plantation to Bossier Parish, Louisiana. Throughout the American Civil War, Mary and their children stayed in South Carolina, but moved to Louisiana in 1866.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Milling Family Papers consist of family correspondence and financial documents from 1852 to 1873. Letters primarily concern plantation life and relations between plantation owners and slaves both prior to and during the Civil War, the secession of South Carolina, enlistment into the Confederate Army of all of Dr. Milling's brothers, John's death at the attack of Fort Harrison, General William Tecumseh Sherman's march through South Carolina, the surrender of the Confederate Army, and the attitudes of Southerners to emancipation. Letters after the Civil War primarily concern relationships between plantation owners and freedmen. A 1997 copy of Confederate Veteran with an article about James A. Milling is also included. The bulk of the correspondence is to Dr. James S. Milling from his father, David Milling, and the bulk of the financial documents relate to business (especially medical) affairs of Dr. James S. Milling. The correspondence is primarily between members living in Bossier Parish, Louisiana; Anderson County, Texas; and Fairfield County, South Carolina.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Milling Family Papers contain three series: I. Correspondence, II. Financial Documents, and III. Printed Materials. All series are arranged chronologically. The Printed Materials series contains only one item.
